newsitem.title: UK: World sugar surplus could limit 97/98 output -Licht.
newsitem.headline: World sugar surplus could limit 97/98 output -Licht.

text.p: The predicted global sugar surplus for 1996/97 could have the effect of limiting production for the following crop year, statistician F.O. Licht said on Thursday.
In its second estimate of the 1996/97 world output, Licht said total production should reach 125.30 million tonnes raw value in 1996/97 or 2.24 million more than in 1995/96.
The extra production would lead to a further build-up in stocks as it was well in excess of consumption needs, it said.
"Though world production will again exceed consumption so that stocks will rise once again, the rate of growth is falling," Licht said.
This partly reflected India's reduced output, it said, but added that the world market price, below production costs in most countries, would also have had taken an effect.
"If there is no major price rise in 1997 - and certainly there is no reason to expect one - this may well have an effect on output in 1997/98," Licht said.

The world sugar surplus was likely to be more widely spread this year and more easily available to world markets, while last year's surplus was mainly locked up in India with only a small amount made available for export.
